text: ありがとう
まったく手間のかかることだ / この町の王子ってどんな人なんだろう
translation: Good grief, what a hassle. / I wonder what kind of person the prince of this town is.
grammar: 「手間のかかる」 is a set phrase meaning 'time-consuming' or 'troublesome'. 「〜ことだ」 adds emphasis. 「〜ってどんな〜なんだろう」 expresses wondering about something.

text: 本来民を守るべき人物が / 逆に町の者たちにその身を案じられておるのだぞ
translation: A person who should be protecting the people / is instead having the townspeople worry about him.

vocabulary.meaning: to worry about, to be concerned about

grammar: Weiss's archaic speech: 「〜べき」 means 'should'. 「案じられておる」 combines passive voice (案じられる) with archaic continuous form (おる instead of いる). 「のだぞ」 is emphatic explanatory ending - 「ぞ」 is masculine/archaic emphasis.

text: わかるだろう
grammar: 「〜だろう」 here is used to seek agreement or confirmation rather than express probability.

text: これはシリオリー
grammar: Fictional Facade language - the masked people of the desert town speak their own constructed language.

text: 無能な死者だ

vocabulary.meaning: leader (likely intended word; 死者 means 'dead person')

grammar: Note: The transcription shows 死者 (dead person), but contextually this is likely 指者 or similar meaning 'leader' - a Facade person commenting critically on the prince.

text: 今何か聞こえたけど

vocabulary.meaning: to be heard, to be audible

grammar: 「〜けど」 at the end leaves the sentence incomplete, implying 'I heard something, but...' - a common conversational pattern expressing uncertainty or trailing off.

text: レイド! / した俺 坊主どこから来たうぐだとあ
grammar: Contains fictional Facade language mixed with Japanese. 「坊主」 is a casual/rough way to address a young person.

text: サントと大神カイラムである 王子ってこんな子供だったんだ / 月たとスケッチ a
translation: (Facade language) The prince was this young of a child!
grammar: 「〜だったんだ」 expresses realization or discovery of something - 'So [it turns out that]...'

text: ああ あああああ / ん
ん
なんだ / えっと / 助けに行かないと
translation: What the-- / Um... / We have to go save him!

vocabulary.meaning: to save, to rescue, to help

grammar: 「〜ないと」 is a contraction of 「〜なければならない」, meaning 'must do' or 'have to'. It leaves the sentence grammatically incomplete but is very common in casual speech.

text: いっそ見なかったことにしたいがな
translation: I'd rather pretend I didn't see that.

vocabulary.meaning: to decide to, to pretend that

grammar: Weiss's speech: 「〜ことにする」 means 'to decide to' or 'to treat as if'. 「〜たいがな」 - 「が」 adds reservation ('but...') and 「な」 is a masculine/archaic sentence-ending particle expressing mild emotion or self-reflection.

text: 死 / ああああああああ / やってられるかこんなの

vocabulary.meaning: can't stand it, unbearable, fed up

grammar: 「やってられるか」 is a rhetorical question form expressing strong frustration - literally 'Can I even do this?!' meaning 'No way I can handle this!' The 「か」 makes it emphatic/rhetorical.

text: 帰れ
grammar: 「帰れ」 is the imperative (command) form of 帰る. The imperative form is created from the え-row of the verb stem and sounds rough/commanding.

text: なんだっこは話せ話し上がれこのくそったれ
translation: What the-- Talk! Speak up, you bastard!
grammar: 「話せ」 is the imperative of 話す. 「くそったれ」 is a vulgar insult combining くそ (crap) with たれ (one who does), typical of Kaine's crude speech.

text: 追いかける相手がもう一人増えたぞ
translation: We've got one more person to chase now.
grammar: 「〜ぞ」 is a masculine sentence-ending particle that adds emphasis or assertion. Weiss uses this archaic/emphatic style.

text: これって
grammar: 「って」 is a casual topic marker equivalent to 「は」. The trailing sentence expresses uncertainty or realization.

text: 見るからに怪しい広間だな
grammar: 「見るからに」 is an idiomatic expression meaning 'obviously' or 'one can tell just by looking'. 「〜だな」 is a masculine sentence ending expressing observation or light assertion.

text: 無目なるかな
translation: How futile... / Alas, it is in vain...
grammar: This is a highly literary/archaic expression. 「〜なるかな」 is classical Japanese exclamatory form expressing lamentation or wonder, similar to 'How [adjective] it is!' Weiss uses such archaic forms.

text: あれ?
あ
奇跡よ / うん、思う存分やれるね
translation: A miracle! / Yeah, we can go all out now.

vocabulary.meaning: to one's heart's content, as much as one wants

grammar: 「思う存分」 is an idiom meaning 'to one's heart's content' or 'without holding back'. 「〜ね」 seeks agreement or confirms shared understanding.

text: 大いもない
grammar: Transcription appears to contain errors.

text: なんとも奇妙な奴だな、過去の消防隊とは
translation: What a strange fellow. The Shades of the past were [different]...
grammar: 「なんとも〜な」 emphasizes the degree of strangeness. Note: 消防隊 (fire brigade) is likely a transcription error; contextually this probably refers to Shades (マモノ).

text: どうやってここに来たの? / 知らん / 暴れたらここに出てきた
translation: How did you get here? / No idea. / I thrashed around and ended up here.

vocabulary.meaning: to thrash about, to rampage, to go wild

grammar: 「知らん」 is a rough/masculine contraction of 「知らない」. 「暴れたら」 uses the conditional 〜たら form meaning 'when I thrashed around'.

text: よくやったぞ / 下によりな / うるさい
translation: Well done. / Come down here. / Shut up!
grammar: Weiss's 「〜ぞ」 is archaic/masculine emphasis. 「下に寄りな」 - 「な」 here is a softened imperative. 「うるさい」 used alone means 'shut up'.

text: カイリア、光る鳩を優先して破壊するのだ
translation: Kaine, prioritize destroying the glowing orbs!
grammar: Weiss's archaic speech: 「〜するのだ」 is a commanding/emphatic form, more formal/archaic than 「〜しろ」. Note: 鳩 (pigeon) is likely a transcription error for 玉 (orb/ball).

text: チキンのモロガミは騙してろ / ギューセもクソもあるか
grammar: 「〜もクソもあるか」 is a vulgar expression meaning 'there's no such thing as X' or dismissing something entirely. Typical of Kaine's crude speech. Transcription contains errors.

text: 全部ぶっ壊せばいいだけだろうが
translation: I just need to destroy everything, right?!
grammar: 「ぶっ〜」 is an emphatic/vulgar prefix that intensifies verbs (from ぶち). 「〜ばいい」 means 'all you need to do is'. 「だろうが」 is aggressive/confrontational sentence ending.

text: 啊
カイラム!
grammar: Facade language. 'Kairam' appears to be the prince's name or title in Facade language.

text: ユリ・ズサラとオタチ!
grammar: Facade language

text: カイザム・セト・ペルア! / カイザム・デサラと言うと
grammar: Facade language

text: シアトとウサトチ・ウレシグ
grammar: Facade language

text: ツグ・コスキ・サオサラへをシエテキッタ / カイザンアサキ
grammar: Facade language

text: カエ サラトアヤーリ / アトルル
grammar: Facade language

text: カイラム
grammar: Facade language

text: オシテキルタチエググ / ギリスアガイ
grammar: Facade language

text: ウカ イヤリ / カイザムアッチ
grammar: Facade language

text: エテスレタダ
grammar: Facade language

text: それでカイザムチタレル
grammar: Facade language

text: チロンテク カイラム / カイザムヨーリン
grammar: Facade language

text: ウラ、トトサラタインター / ゾスローであった
grammar: Facade language

text: ベルアト、カイザムセテ、鉄砂枠
grammar: Facade language

text: ゴレ、トルヨーリン
grammar: Facade language

text: いや、そんなお礼だなんて
translation: No, you don't need to thank me like that...
grammar: 「〜だなんて」 expresses that something is too much or unnecessary, often used when humbly declining praise or thanks.

text: 遠離探査クルター統合
grammar: Facade language - contains some recognizable kanji but is part of the constructed Facade language.

text: まるで脅迫だな
grammar: 「まるで〜だ」 means 'it's just like...' or 'as if...'. Weiss is commenting that the Facade people's insistence sounds like a threat.

text: じゃあ掟ゼロとして気に入らない掟は住民投票で変えることができるってのはどうかな
translation: Then how about this as Rule Zero: any rule you don't like can be changed by popular vote?

vocabulary.meaning: to like, to be pleased with
to not like, to be displeased with

vocabulary.reading: じゅうみんとうひょう

grammar: 「〜ってのは」 is casual for 「〜というのは」 meaning 'the idea that...'. 「どうかな」 is a casual way to propose or suggest something, seeking the listener's opinion.

text: 名案だ / ヨーリサロー

vocabulary.meaning: good idea, brilliant plan, excellent suggestion

grammar: 「名案」 literally means 'famous/excellent plan'. The Facade language response appears to express agreement/approval.

text: エルパチスチタ / ペルアト
grammar: Facade language

text: ルトシ恩寺はくれたい / ペルアトとタトだ
grammar: Facade language

text: アンダサンキトシチ / テトヨウリュウ
grammar: Facade language

text: エオーカイザム / サラトはシュエテキッタ
grammar: Facade language

text: コスキウカエテスレタだ
grammar: Facade language

text: ありがとう / でも王のために一番頑張ったのは / 僕たちじゃないよ
translation: Thank you. / But we weren't the ones who worked hardest for the king.

vocabulary.meaning: to do one's best, to work hard, to persevere

grammar: 「〜のは」 nominalizes the preceding clause ('the one who worked hardest'). 「〜じゃないよ」 is casual negation with 「よ」 adding assertion.

text: 毛渡った
grammar: Transcription appears to contain errors.

text: 黒紋病の治療方法について / 何か知らないかな
translation: Do you know anything about how to cure the Black Scrawl?
grammar: 「〜について」 means 'about/concerning'. 「知らないかな」 is a gentle, hopeful way of asking 'do you perhaps know?'

text: 素数よ / ライザムで
grammar: Contains Facade language. 「素数」 (prime number) may be a transcription error.

text: 糸つきた / やっぱり / 王様でも治らなかったんだ
translation: I see... / As expected, / even the king couldn't be cured.

vocabulary.meaning: as expected, after all, sure enough
to be cured, to heal, to recover

grammar: 「〜でも」 after a noun means 'even'. 「〜なかったんだ」 expresses realization of a past fact with emotional weight.

text: 手 / 図式だとだ / やはり / 地道に封印されし言葉を / 集めるしかないようだ
translation: It seems we have no choice but to steadily collect the Sealed Verses.
grammar: Weiss's archaic speech: 「封印されし」 uses the classical past attributive form 「〜し」 (modern: 「〜した」), meaning 'that which was sealed'. 「〜しかない」 means 'have no choice but to'. 「〜ようだ」 expresses appearance or conjecture.

text: そうだね / それしか手がかりはないしね
translation: You're right. / That's our only lead after all.
grammar: 「〜しか〜ない」 means 'only' or 'nothing but'. 「〜しね」 ends the sentence with agreement-seeking (し adds reason, ね seeks confirmation).

text: ウィンカレキソと
grammar: Facade language

text: それらを集めると / 国問病が治せるっていう / 古い言い伝えがあるらしいんだよ
translation: There's apparently an old legend that says if you collect them all, / you can cure the Black Scrawl.
grammar: 「〜っていう」 is casual for 「〜という」 (called, that says). 「〜らしい」 indicates hearsay or conjecture. 「〜んだよ」 adds explanatory emphasis. Note: 国問病 appears to be a transcription error for 黒紋病.

text: 伝説というだけでそこに信憑性はないかな
translation: Just because it's a legend doesn't mean there's no credibility to it.
grammar: 「〜というだけで」 means 'just because it's called/is'. 「〜ないかな」 expresses wondering or hoping that something might be the case. Weiss suggests legends shouldn't be dismissed entirely.

text: ヨナを助けられる可能性が少しでもあるのなら
translation: If there's even the slightest chance of saving Yonah...
grammar: 「少しでも」 emphasizes 'even a little bit'. 「〜のなら」 is a conditional meaning 'if it is the case that...'. The sentence trails off, implying strong determination.

text: 何だって信じるよ / 言葉だろうがオーブだろうがクリスタルだろうが / 命がけで集めまくってやる
translation: I'll believe anything. / Whether it's words, orbs, or crystals, / I'll collect them all even if it costs me my life.

vocabulary.meaning: to collect like crazy, to gather extensively

grammar: 「〜だろうが〜だろうが」 means 'whether it's... or...' (listing possibilities). 「〜まくる」 is an emphatic suffix meaning 'to do extensively/intensely'. 「〜てやる」 shows determination to do something (slightly rough).

text: あ、アド
grammar: Appears to be an incomplete utterance or transcription issue.

text: た、あこちしてすれたいさ
grammar: Facade language

text: そんな、とだちときて
grammar: Facade language - likely the prince expressing emotion. May contain 「友達」 (tomodachi, friend).

text: もちろん
もう誘拐されるでないぞ
grammar: Weiss's archaic speech: 「〜でないぞ」 is an archaic prohibitive form meaning 'do not ~'. Modern equivalent would be 「〜するな」 or 「〜しないでね」. The 「ぞ」 adds masculine emphasis.

text: たく、とうち、たく
grammar: Facade language

text: ヨナが心配だ / そろそろ戻ろう
translation: I'm worried about Yonah. / Let's head back soon.

vocabulary.meaning: soon, before long, any moment now

grammar: 「〜が心配だ」 means 'to be worried about ~'. 「〜ろう」 is the volitional form expressing 'let's do ~' or intention to do something.
